conclusion: Break down the motion of the charged particle into motion in the magnetic field and motion in the electric field.
The particle enters the magnetic field at the origin O with an initial velocity vi at a 45-degree angle to the y-axis.
The particle will follow a circular path in the fourth quadrant due to the perpendicular inward magnetic field.
The component of the initial velocity in the x-direction is vi/sqrt(2) and in the y-direction is vi/sqrt(2).
The time period of one complete revolution in the magnetic field is T = 2πm/qB.
The time spent in the magnetic field is t1 = πm/2qB since the particle covers a quarter of the circle.
After completing a quarter of the circle, the particle will be at point Q with coordinates (R, -R).
Using the relation R = mvi/qB, the coordinates of Q are (mvi/qB, -mvi/qB).
At point Q, the velocity of the particle will be vi√2 directed at a 45-degree angle to the x-axis.
The particle experiences a force F = qE in the negative y-direction when it enters the electric field.
The x-component of the velocity remains constant, so vx = vi.
The time t2 required to reach P can be calculated by considering the motion in the x and y directions separately.
The x-coordinate equation is 3L - R = vi t2, so t2 = (3L - R)/vi.
The y-coordinate equation is L + R = (1/2) (qE/m) t2^2, solving for t2 gives t2 = sqrt(2(L+R)m/qE).
The total time taken for the particle to move from point O to point P is t_total = t1 + t2 = πm/2qB + sqrt(2(L+R)m/qE).
Substituting R = mvi/qB in the expression for t2 gives the final answer: πm/2qB + sqrt(2(L + mvi/qB)m/qE).
